intro: Cuphea barbigera, commonly known as the woolly cuphea, is a flowering plant native to Central America. It is characterized by its soft, hairy foliage and showy, spike-like inflorescences that bloom in shades of red, pink, and purple. The plant typically grows as an annual or perennial herb, reaching heights of up to 3 feet. Its flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, making it a valuable addition to gardens. The plant thrives in full sun to partial shade and well-drained soil, requiring moderate water to flourish.
